By changing ServerOpt, we can recover methods such as FedAvgM (Hsu et al., 2019) (server gradient descent with momentum), and FedAdam (Reddi et al., 2020) (server Adam (Kingma and Ba, 2014)).

S4.T2.caption: Table 2: Convergence rates of LocalUpdate when ServerOpt is gradient descent (with or without momentum), and κ=κ​(α,γ,Θ)𝜅𝜅𝛼𝛾Θ\kappa=\kappa(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta) is as in (9).
references: To remedy this, we compare local update algorithms on the basis of both convergence and accuracy. Instead of fixing γ𝛾\gamma and ΘΘ\Theta, we analyze LocalUpdate as γ𝛾\gamma and K​(Θ)𝐾ΘK(\Theta) vary. To do so, we use our theory from Section 4. Given α,γ𝛼𝛾\alpha,\gamma and ΘΘ\Theta, we define the convergence rate ρ​(α,γ,Θ)𝜌𝛼𝛾Θ\rho(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta) as the infimum over all ρ𝜌\rho such that for all T≥1𝑇1T\geq 1, (14) holds. Values of ρ𝜌\rho when ServerOpt is gradient descent are given in Table 2. For Θ=Θ1:KΘsubscriptΘ:1𝐾\Theta=\Theta_{1:K} or ΘKsubscriptΘ𝐾\Theta_{K}, we define the suboptimality Δ​(α,γ,Θ)Δ𝛼𝛾Θ\Delta(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta) by

As shown empirically by Hsu et al. (2019) and as reflected in Table 2, server momentum can improve convergence. To understand this, in Figure 2 we compare Pareto frontiers where Θ=Θ1:KΘsubscriptΘ:1𝐾\Theta=\Theta_{1:K} and ServerOpt is gradient descent with various types of momentum (Nesterov, heavy-ball, or no momentum). We see a strict ordering of the server optimization methods. Heavy-ball momentum is better than Nesterov momentum, which is better than no momentum.

By Lemma 1, ρ𝜌\rho and ΔΔ\Delta are still well-defined for ΘKsubscriptΘ𝐾\Theta_{K} when (K​L+α)−1≤γ<(L+α)−1superscript𝐾𝐿𝛼1𝛾superscript𝐿𝛼1(KL+\alpha)^{-1}\leq\gamma<(L+\alpha)^{-1}.
To understand what happens in this regime, we generate random symmetric A∈ℝd×d𝐴superscriptℝ𝑑𝑑A\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times d} satisfying cond(A)=L/μcond𝐴𝐿𝜇\operatorname*{cond}(A)=L/\mu and compute Q​(α,γ,ΘK)𝑄𝛼𝛾subscriptΘ𝐾Q(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta_{K}) as in (6). We then compute κ𝜅\kappa via (9), and plug this into Table 2 and (17) to get ρ,Δ𝜌Δ\rho,\Delta. This gives us a simulated Pareto frontier for ΘKsubscriptΘ𝐾\Theta_{K}, which we compare to Θ1:KsubscriptΘ:1𝐾\Theta_{1:K} in Figure 5. For details and additional experiments, see Appendix D.1.

In order to plot Pareto frontiers for MAML-style methods (Θ=ΘKΘsubscriptΘ𝐾\Theta=\Theta_{K}) when γ>(K​L+α)−1𝛾superscript𝐾𝐿𝛼1\gamma>(KL+\alpha)^{-1}, we generate random symmetric matrices A∈ℝd×d𝐴superscriptℝ𝑑𝑑A\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times d} satisfying μ​I⪯A⪯L​Iprecedes-or-equals𝜇𝐼𝐴precedes-or-equals𝐿𝐼\mu I\preceq A\preceq LI. We then compute the associated matrix Q​(α,γ,ΘK)𝑄𝛼𝛾subscriptΘ𝐾Q(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta_{K}). Once we have these matrices, we can compute the condition number κ𝜅\kappa of Q​(α,γ,ΘK)​A𝑄𝛼𝛾subscriptΘ𝐾𝐴Q(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta_{K})A. We can then compute ρ,Δ𝜌Δ\rho,\Delta by substituting κ𝜅\kappa into Table 2 and Lemma 5.

In short, we see clear evidence that the choice of client learning rate γ𝛾\gamma leads to a trade-off between convergence and accuracy. However, as shown in Lemmas 3 and 4, the condition number of the surrogate loss changes depending on parameters such as γ𝛾\gamma. To derive asymptotically optimal rates for strongly convex functions (such as the ones in Table 2), one must generally set the learning rate η𝜂\eta according to the condition number. Thus, we repeat the experiments in Figure 12, but where we tune the server learning rate η𝜂\eta instead of fixing it. This helps account for how the optimization dynamics can change as a function of the client learning rate γ𝛾\gamma. We vary the server learning rate η𝜂\eta over

and select η𝜂\eta that leads to the smallest average training loss over the last 100 rounds. The result is given in Figure 13. Again, we see similar behavior, but see that when the server learning rate is tuned, larger client learning rates may do much better initially. This reflects the fact that in Table 2, the best convergence rates can only be obtained by setting parameters of ServerOpt correctly.

A5.T3.caption: Table 3: Dataset statistics.
A5.T3.table:
Dataset Train Clients Train Examples Test Clients Test Examples
FEMNIST 3,400 671,585 3,400 77,483
CIFAR-100 500 50,000 100 10,000
Shakespeare 715 16,068 715 2,356
references: We use three datasets: the federated extended MNIST dataset (FEMNIST) (Caldas et al., 2018), CIFAR-100 (Krizhevsky and Hinton, 2009), and Shakespeare (Caldas et al., 2018). The first two are image datasets, and the third is a language dataset. All datasets are publicly available. We specifically use the versions available in TensorFlow Federated (Ingerman and Ostrowski, 2019), which gives a federated structure to all three. We keep the client partitioning when training, and create a test dataset by taking a union over all test client datasets. Statistics on the number of clients and examples in each dataset are given in Table 3.
